children.text: Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026
36.1	The proposed regular budget resources for staff assessment for 2026, including the breakdown of resource changes, as applicable, are reflected in the table below.
Table – Overall: evolution of financial resources by object of expenditure

36.2	In accordance with the established budgetary practice, provisions for staff assessment are made by applying the rates contained in regulation 3.3 of the Staff Regulations and Rules of the United Nations to the assessable emoluments of United Nations staff. The staff assessment amounts resulting from the application of such rates are consolidated under the present section, while the provisions for salaries are presented under other budget sections. The provisions for salaries represent the net amounts, while the gross amounts include staff assessment in addition to the net salary provisions. The gross and net amounts related to each budget section are presented in the annex to the present document.

36.3	Amounts from staff assessment are credited upfront to Member States to offset assessments for the budget period, with the exception of staff assessment credits withheld and credited to the Tax Equalization Fund for the reimbursement of taxes on emoluments of United Nations staff members, as envisaged in General Assembly resolution 973 (X) A. The amount proposed under the present section is also reflected under income section 1, Income from staff assessment (A/80/6 (Income sect.1)).

36.4	The overall resources proposed for 2026 amount to $325,352,900 before recosting, reflecting a net decrease of $2,783,200 (or 0.8 per cent) compared with the approved budget for 2025. Resource changes result from three factors: (a) technical adjustments; (b) new and expanded mandates; and (c) other changes.

36.5	As presented in the table above, resource changes reflect a net increase of $1,358,000, resulting from an increase of $1,437,100 related to the additional posts proposed in support of the various mandates approved by the General Assembly, which were subject to a 50 per cent vacancy rate in 2025 and are now budgeted at continuing rates in accordance with the established practice, and an increase of $388,700 in the provisions for special political missions; offset in part by a decrease of $467,800 due to the discontinuation of non-recurrent provisions under other staff costs under various other sections of the proposed programme budget for 2026.

36.6	Resource changes resulting from new or expanded mandates approved by the General Assembly reflect a net decrease of $7,484,000, attributable to a decrease of $8,702,300 in the special political missions, due mainly to the expiration of mandates for the United Nations Assistance Mission for Iraq pursuant to Security Council resolution 2732 (2024) and the United Nations Transitional Assistance Mission in Somalia pursuant to Security Council resolution 2753 (2024). The decrease is offset in part by an increase of $1,218,300, attributable mainly to the proposed net increase in posts and positions under various sections of the proposed programme budget for 2026.

36.7	As reflected in the table above, resource changes reflect a net increase of $3,342,800, resulting from a proposed increase of $3,734,000 due to the increase in the number of posts and positions, offset in part by a decrease of $391,200 in the provisions for general temporary assistance replacement under various other sections of the proposed programme budget for 2026.
Annex – Overall: evolution of resources by budget section, showing net and gross amounts (before recosting)
